**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, \u00a7\u00a7.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 218, §§ 19 and 21**, as the amount in controversy does not exceed the District Court’s jurisdictional limit and the cause of action arose in Lynn, Massachusetts.

**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 148, \u00a7 26F**.proposition: Pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 148, § 26F** and **780 C.M.R. § 907.2.10.2.1**, smoke detectors are required in common hallways of multi-unit residential buildings and must be properly maintained in working order.

**780 C.M.R. \u00a7 907.2.10.2.1**.proposition: Pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 148, § 26F** and **780 C.M.R. § 907.2.10.2.1**, smoke detectors are required in common hallways of multi-unit residential buildings and must be properly maintained in working order.

**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes upon landlords a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas of leased premises in a safe condition. **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 167 (1980); **King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass. 658, 660 (1977).
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly discusses and reaffirms that, under prior Massachusetts law, a landlord owed a duty of reasonable care to maintain common areas in a safe condition, citing King v. G & M Realty Corp. It distinguishes that existing rule (common areas under landlord control) from the then-new rule it adopts regarding leased premises themselves, making clear that the duty for common areas already existed. Thus, it supports the proposition that Massachusetts law imposes such a duty for common areas.
**Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 16.relevant_excerpt: The landlord "was under a separate and limited duty toward each tenant and that tenant’s visitors to exercise reasonable care to maintain the common areas in a condition not less safe than they were, or appeared to be in, at the time of the letting to the particular tenant." King v. G & M Realty Corp., 373 Mass. 658, 660 (1977). Lindsey v. Massios, 372 Mass. 79, 81-82 (1977). In the landlord-tenant field, we have held that a landlord is liable to a tenant’s guest for failing to exercise due care in maintaining common passageways under the landlord’s control without regard to their condition at the time of the letting.

**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass.raw_text: **King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass. 658, 660 (1977)
**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts law imposes upon landlords a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain common areas of leased premises in a safe condition. **Young v. Garwacki**, 380 Mass. 162, 167 (1980); **King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass. 658, 660 (1977).
**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass.case_name: King v. G & M REALTY CORP.
**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly rejects the old limited Massachusetts rule and adopts the modern rule that a landlord owes a general, continuing duty of reasonable care to maintain common areas in a safe condition. The court holds that this duty runs to tenants themselves (not just their guests) and approves a jury instruction imposing a “general, continuing duty” to keep the common stairway safe. Thus, King directly supports the cited proposition about Massachusetts landlords’ duty regarding common areas.
**King v. G & M Realty Corp.**, 373 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “In the past it was the law of the Commonwealth that a landlord had no general obligation to exercise reasonable care in keeping safe the common areas… Rather he was under a separate and limited duty… This was a singular Massachusetts rule… In Lindsey v. Massios… we… joined the current of authority… The present case is the one reserved. We think the measure of the landlord’s responsibility to the tenant with respect to common areas left in the landlord’s control should not differ… The trial judge was thus correct in charging the jury as he did.”

**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, \u00a7 15B(1).proposition: Defendant owed Plaintiff a duty to keep the common hallway and its safety systems, including the smoke detector, in a condition that would not subject her to unreasonable risk of harm. See **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 186, § 15B(1)(a)** (landlords must comply with applicable code requirements and maintain premises in habitable condition).

**Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 C.M.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain a working smoke detector violated the standards of care established by **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 148, § 26F**, **780 C.M.R. § 907.2.10.2.1**, and related provisions of the **Massachusetts State Fire Code (527 C.M.R. 1.00)**.

**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.raw_text: **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990)
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.proposition: Violation of such safety statutes and regulations constitutes evidence of negligence. **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990); **Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.**, 267 Mass. 501, 519 (1929).
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses the legal effect of violating G.L. c. 138, § 69, and reiterates the settled Massachusetts rule that such a statutory violation is not negligence per se but is admissible as evidence of negligence. The court explicitly characterizes violation of § 69 as only “some evidence” of negligence as to the harms the statute was intended to prevent, which aligns with the claimed proposition that violations of such safety statutes and regulations constitute evidence (though not conclusive proof) of negligence.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.relevant_excerpt: “It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se… Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only ‘some evidence’ of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).”

**Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.**.proposition: Violation of such safety statutes and regulations constitutes evidence of negligence. **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 358 (1990); **Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.**, 267 Mass. 501, 519 (1929).
**Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.**.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that violation of a statute, ordinance, or regulation is evidence of negligence, not conclusive proof, and then applies that principle to the defendant’s violation of the fire prevention regulation regarding safe disposal of scrap film. This matches the proposition that violation of safety statutes and regulations constitutes evidence of negligence, and the court cites earlier Massachusetts authority to affirm that rule.
**Guinan v. Famous Players-Lasky Corp.**.relevant_excerpt: “There was evidence from which the jury could properly find that the delivery of the scrap film by Doherty to Shirley in a burlap bag was not a safe disposal of it. The regulations have the force and effect of law. A violation of a statute, ordinance or regulation, although not conclusive, is evidence of negligence on the part of a violator as to all consequences that the statute, ordinance or regulation was intended to prevent. Wright v. Malden & Melrose Railroad, 4 Allen, 283, 290. Lane v. Atlantic Works, 111 Mass. 136, 140. …”

**Lyon v. Morphew**, 424 Mass. 828, 834.proposition: Defendant further breached its common-law duty of reasonable care by disregarding repeated notice of the inoperative detector and failing to act in a timely manner. **Lyon v. Morphew**, 424 Mass. 828, 834 (1997).
**Lyon v. Morphew**, 424 Mass. 828, 834.support_reasoning: The proposition asserts that a defendant breached a common-law duty of reasonable care by ignoring repeated notice of an inoperative detector and failing to act timely—essentially a premises safety/maintenance theory involving notice and failure to correct. Lyon v. Morphew involves personal liability of hospital employees for removal/nonreplacement of a roof safety railing and for not directing an independent contractor to install safety devices. The court holds there was no common-law or statutory duty to provide or maintain such roof fall protection and rejects liability; it does not discuss detectors, repeated notice, or a duty triggered by such notice, and in fact is contrary to the idea that failing to install safety protections breached a duty. Thus it does not support the claimed proposition.
**Lyon v. Morphew**, 424 Mass. 828, 834.relevant_excerpt: "From the evidence viewed in a light most favorable to the plaintiff, it could be inferred that they played a role in determining whether the hospital should replace the railing or install an alternative safety device; however, they had no common law or statutory duty to do either. ... We have never recognized a common law duty of building owners to place or maintain fall protection safety devices on roofs."

**Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc..raw_text: **Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc.**, 277 Mass. 440, 445 (1931)
**Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc..proposition: Defendant’s negligent omissions directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries, including smoke inhalation, respiratory distress, medical bills, lost wages, and damage to personal property. **Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc.**, 277 Mass. 440, 445 (1931); **Bergeron v. Forest Realty Co.**, 322 Mass. 475, 479 (1948).
**Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc..case_name: Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc.
**Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether the decedent was a nonresident entitled to operate under an out‑of‑state registration or was required to have a Massachusetts registration, and the consequence that an unregistered vehicle is an ‘outlaw’ on the highway. It does not analyze proximate cause, types of damages, or link negligent omissions to specific injuries such as smoke inhalation, respiratory distress, medical expenses, lost wages, or property damage. The case is about statutory status and legality of operation, not causation or the scope of compensable damages, so it does not support the cited proposition.
**Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc..relevant_excerpt:
If the deceased had become a resident of Massachusetts prior to the accident he was required to have his automobile registered under the laws of this Commonwealth and was not entitled with respect to it to the rights of a nonresident. Hanson v. Culton, 269 Mass. 471.

The circumstance that the decedent may have been upon the road examining his own automobile at the time of his injury did not prevent him from being found to be operating his automobile contrary to law and being an outlaw upon the highway.

**Bergeron v. Forest Realty Co.**, 322 M.proposition: Defendant’s negligent omissions directly and proximately caused Plaintiff’s injuries, including smoke inhalation, respiratory distress, medical bills, lost wages, and damage to personal property. **Jenkins v. North Shore Dye House, Inc.**, 277 Mass. 440, 445 (1931); **Bergeron v. Forest Realty Co.**, 322 Mass. 475, 479 (1948).
**Bergeron v. Forest Realty Co.**, 322 M.support_reasoning: Bergeron v. Forest Realty Co. is a conversion case about wrongful dominion over rayon linings and the resulting special damages from interruption of business, not a negligence case involving proximate cause of personal injuries such as smoke inhalation, respiratory distress, medical bills, or lost wages. The opinion addresses measure of damages for conversion and when special consequential business-interruption damages are recoverable, not causation of bodily injury or property damage in negligence. It therefore does not support the specific negligence‑causation proposition stated.
**Bergeron v. Forest Realty Co.**, 322 M.relevant_excerpt: “As to the requested ruling on the measure of damages, it is true that for a conversion the plaintiff ordinarily is entitled to recover the fair and reasonable market value of the property with interest from the time of conversion… But where there is evidence of special injury, such as interruption of a business, further damages may be awarded. Costa v. Goldenberg, 258 Mass. 264. Whitcomb v. Reed-Prentice Co. 262 Mass. 348, 359. Potier v. A. W. Perry, Inc. 286 Mass. 602, 606.”

**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.raw_text: **Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.**, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996)
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.proposition: The harm suffered by Plaintiff was foreseeable, as the purpose of smoke detection equipment is to provide warning of exactly the type of hazard that occurred. **Poskus v. Lombardo’s of Randolph, Inc.**, 423 Mass. 637, 640 (1996).
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.case_name: Poskus v. Lombardo's of Randolph, Inc.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Poskus does not state that the harm was foreseeable or that the purpose of a safety device makes such harm foreseeable. Instead, both the majority (as referenced) and the concurrence conclude that the plaintiff’s injuries were not within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by the defendant’s negligence. The proposition reverses the case’s actual conclusion and thus misstates its authority on foreseeability.
**Poskus v. Lombardo\u2019s of Randolph,.relevant_excerpt: “I concur in the view that ‘[t]he facts would not warrant a jury’s finding that the plaintiff’s injuries were within the reasonably foreseeable risk of harm created by Lombardo’s negligence.’ Ante at 640-641.”

**Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*.raw_text: **Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**, 905 F.2d 515, 520 (1st Cir. 1990)
**Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries would not have occurred but for Defendant’s negligence in failing to maintain the smoke detector in operable condition. **Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**, 905 F.2d 515, 520 (1st Cir. 1990) (applying Massachusetts law).
**Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*.case_name: Lisa Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Authority, Appeal of Donald Hertzfeldt and Peter Langley
**Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*.support_reasoning: The opinion does not involve smoke detectors or a failure to maintain a smoke detector in operable condition, nor does it contain any holding that plaintiffs’ injuries would not have occurred but for such negligence. Instead, it concerns whether reputational damages are recoverable in an ordinary negligence action and whether plaintiffs proved proximate cause for reputation-related losses arising from an airplane accident on an icy runway. Thus, citing this case for a but‑for causation proposition about smoke detector maintenance misrepresents its holding and context.
**Jorgensen v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*.relevant_excerpt: “Under Massachusetts law, proximate cause requires a showing by the plaintiff, first, that the loss was a foreseeable consequence of the defendant's negligence, second, that the defendant's negligence was a but-for cause of the loss, and third, that the defendant's negligence was a substantial factor in bringing about the loss.” 905 F.2d at 535 (internal citations omitted).

**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7 85**.proposition: Plaintiff did not contribute to the cause of the malfunctioning alarm or fire, and her actions were reasonable under the circumstances. See **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, § 85** (comparative negligence).

**Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. C.raw_text: **Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.**, 316 Mass. 626, 629 (1944)
**Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. C.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover all reasonably foreseeable damages caused by Defendant’s breach. **Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. Co.**, 316 Mass. 626, 629 (1944).
**Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. C.case_name: Damiano v. National Grange Mutual Liability Co.
**Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. C.support_reasoning: The opinion does not address the measure of damages for breach of contract or any rule about recovery of all reasonably foreseeable damages. Instead, it holds that a plaintiff is at least entitled to nominal damages upon breach and discusses pleading sufficiency, not the full scope of recoverable consequential damages. Thus, citing this case for a foreseeability-based damages rule misstates its holding.
**Damiano v. National Grange Mut. Ins. C.relevant_excerpt: “It was not necessary for the plaintiff to allege any damage resulting from the breach of the agreement properly to defend. When a contract has been broken by a defendant, the plaintiff ‘is entitled to a verdict for nominal damages for the breach, if nothing more. For every breach of a promise made on good consideration, the law awards some damage.’”

**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, \u00a7\u00a7.proposition: Award costs and interest pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 231, §§ 6B and 6C**;
